_data.title: The making of Asauna experience

toc.text: The toughest project I've worked on
Full-stack development solo takes a long time

children.value: For a more detailed look on how working on projects is like.
See the blog where I wrote about
Asauna is a project management program based off the popular app, Asana.
It was the project management app of choice that we used at ESC-Toy ltd. and I thought it would be a fun challenge to create this project to impress my old boss.
To do lists are pretty fun to make, and it's the most common type of app people use in order to teach people and I can see why.
The toughest project I've worked on

It has the basic create, read, update, and delete functions that all databases use.
That first project got me warmed up, so now it’s time to do this on my own. The project I cloned was a task management system called Asana. I picked this app because it was the program I used when I was working at my previous job and wanted to show it to my boss when I get it presentable.

The technologies I used in creating this app was React/JS to render the visuals, Express/JS with Sequelize for the backend, but this time in two seperate servers with proxies. To make my project styling consistent, I used a library called Material-UI. It is the most popular React UI framework at the time and the documentation has a lot of great snippets and examples.
One of the problems I faced was pretty hard to swallow because it’s something I’ve been before without realizing it. I wanted to make two different components render the same message when either was changed.
Time felt a lot faster and it seemed like there was more work to do compared to while I was working in a group. Also more draining because progress is much slower.

My first instinct was to go search for the solution for the answer, but I just couldn’t find it.
The one action I took to solve this problem was very simple. I just posted my code snippet on slack and asked for suggestions.
It is very important to ask for questions, because someone can have an answer.
Even though it’s a solo project, asking help and suggestions is still highly advised and that’s what I did.

Working solo adds a lot of stress and makes it hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel.
After solving that, I realized that the problem goes beyond lack of understanding, but the mental fog that builds up when working for too long so I learned something new from it.
I still feel proud of my solo project just for the fact that I was the key creator in this app and took ownership of it.
In my future solo project, I managed to create a better system by using React Context instead of passing down props.
Bring up the chrome inspector, use debugger/ break points.

I've used Chrome extensions to further enhacing my debugging capabilities in production mode by adding Redux Devtools. This made it easier for me to view Redux state without having the print to the console. Cross Origin Resource Sharing was a problem I had earlier when seperating my front end from the backend, and it was solved easily by adding the CORS middleware to the backend. Aside from using Chrome inspector, I also use Postman to test API calls.

Error checking and displaying them is vital for full stack applications since it is difficult to spot backend errors due to having little to no visual cues and the asynchronous unpredictability of network connections. I think it takes a lot of manual work to figure out if the API error is a frontend or backend error. By using the debugger and stepping in and out of the processes. If this doesn't work, then I would try debugging again with parameters I know would succeed to try to understand why this one works and the other one doesn't. 404 errors while fetching from an API usually means for me that I've sent it to the wrong URL and my frontend routing incorrect. If I get a 422 error unprocessible entity, that could be that I'm not passing in correct parameters from the frontend to the backend so I have to make sure what I'm passing in is what the backend is willing to accept. On the other hand, if I know what I'm sending the backend is 100% accurate, then a 422 error would mean that messed up on proccessing the data in the backend deals with the database, whether it be creating entries, joining models, relationships, querying the wrong entries, etc.

The frontend also has its challenges. Solving visual errors relies on my creative thinking and searching for hints online since they're usually not spotted by the compiler unless it's a common error such as a reference or syntax error. I think state management is one of the tougher things to debug depending on how much components are dependant on it.If there are any problems with state management, I would probably solve it by stepping through the debugger and trying to find out where the error might occur.

Error checking and displaying them is something I try to do when I'm working on full stack applications. It is difficult to spot fetch requests or state errors due to having asynchronous nature and little to no visual cues. I have used the browser inspectors has helped me deal with a lot of bugs I have solved. I also use Chrome extensions in production mode to further enhancing my debugging capabilities, such as the Redux Devtools. This made it easier for me to view Redux state without having the print to the console. Cross Origin Resource Sharing was a problem I had earlier when separating my front end from the backend, and it was solved easily by adding the CORS middleware to the backend. Aside from using Chrome inspector, I also use Postman to test our authentication, authorization, API requests other than GET etc.

The debugger has helped me a lot, I fixed 422 unprocessable entities and props/ state errors by stepping in and out of the processes. I would try this with my original data, and later with parameters I know would succeed, just to get an idea of why this one works and the other one doesn't. I figured out that 404 errors happen while fetching from the wrong API URL so I messed up in my routing somewhere. I have gotten alot better at organizing code.
First time using React definitely made my code seem a little more organized.
Never realized how much mental energy working 100% solo can be.
I have worked on my own tasks individually on my last group project.
It's been incredibly diffult to know when to stop.

I feel most productive in the first 3 hours of work, but then my brain starts to go on a decline when it is lunch time, then get another burst of focus, and then completely dying off 2 or 3 hours later until the end of class.
I felt like I was behind, so I decided to stay up all night with no sleep.
And then I was performing poorly in the morning, the time where I was the most productive.
It may not be perfect, but it is my creation and I'm willing to share my thoughts about the process and what I have learned.

_data.text: ![Asauna header](/images/headers/asauna-header.png "Asauna header") For a more detailed look on how working on projects is like. *See the blog where I wrote about App Academy projects.* ## What is Asauna? Asauna is a project management program based off the popular app, Asana. ## Why this? It was the project management app of choice that we used at ESC-Toy ltd. and I thought it would be a fun challenge to create this project to impress my old boss. To do lists are pretty fun to make, and it's the most common type of app people use in order to teach people and I can see why. ## The toughest project I've worked on It has the basic create, read, update, and delete functions that all databases use. That first project got me warmed up, so now it’s time to do this on my own. The project I cloned was a task management system called Asana. I picked this app because it was the program I used when I was working at my previous job and wanted to show it to my boss when I get it presentable. ## Technologies The technologies I used in creating this app was React/JS to render the visuals, Express/JS with Sequelize for the backend, but this time in two seperate servers with proxies. To make my project styling consistent, I used a library called Material-UI. It is the most popular React UI framework at the time and the documentation has a lot of great snippets and examples. One of the problems I faced was pretty hard to swallow because it’s something I’ve been before without realizing it. I wanted to make two different components render the same message when either was changed. Time felt a lot faster and it seemed like there was more work to do compared to while I was working in a group. Also more draining because progress is much slower. My first instinct was to go search for the solution for the answer, but I just couldn’t find it. The one action I took to solve this problem was very simple. I just posted my code snippet on slack and asked for suggestions. It is very important to ask for questions, because someone can have an answer. Even though it’s a solo project, asking help and suggestions is still highly advised and that’s what I did. Working solo adds a lot of stress and makes it hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel. After solving that, I realized that the problem goes beyond lack of understanding, but the mental fog that builds up when working for too long so I learned something new from it. I still feel proud of my solo project just for the fact that I was the key creator in this app and took ownership of it. In my future solo project, I managed to create a better system by using React Context instead of passing down props. ## Learning the importance of debugging Bring up the chrome inspector, use debugger/ break points. I've used Chrome extensions to further enhacing my debugging capabilities in production mode by adding Redux Devtools. This made it easier for me to view Redux state without having the print to the console. Cross Origin Resource Sharing was a problem I had earlier when seperating my front end from the backend, and it was solved easily by adding the CORS middleware to the backend. Aside from using Chrome inspector, I also use Postman to test API calls. Error checking and displaying them is vital for full stack applications since it is difficult to spot backend errors due to having little to no visual cues and the asynchronous unpredictability of network connections. I think it takes a lot of manual work to figure out if the API error is a frontend or backend error. By using the debugger and stepping in and out of the processes. If this doesn't work, then I would try debugging again with parameters I know would succeed to try to understand why this one works and the other one doesn't. 404 errors while fetching from an API usually means for me that I've sent it to the wrong URL and my frontend routing incorrect. If I get a 422 error unprocessible entity, that could be that I'm not passing in correct parameters from the frontend to the backend so I have to make sure what I'm passing in is what the backend is willing to accept. On the other hand, if I know what I'm sending the backend is 100% accurate, then a 422 error would mean that messed up on proccessing the data in the backend deals with the database, whether it be creating entries, joining models, relationships, querying the wrong entries, etc. The frontend also has its challenges. Solving visual errors relies on my creative thinking and searching for hints online since they're usually not spotted by the compiler unless it's a common error such as a reference or syntax error. I think state management is one of the tougher things to debug depending on how much components are dependant on it.If there are any problems with state management, I would probably solve it by stepping through the debugger and trying to find out where the error might occur. Error checking and displaying them is something I try to do when I'm working on full stack applications. It is difficult to spot fetch requests or state errors due to having asynchronous nature and little to no visual cues. I have used the browser inspectors has helped me deal with a lot of bugs I have solved. I also use Chrome extensions in production mode to further enhancing my debugging capabilities, such as the Redux Devtools. This made it easier for me to view Redux state without having the print to the console. Cross Origin Resource Sharing was a problem I had earlier when separating my front end from the backend, and it was solved easily by adding the CORS middleware to the backend. Aside from using Chrome inspector, I also use Postman to test our authentication, authorization, API requests other than GET etc. The debugger has helped me a lot, I fixed 422 unprocessable entities and props/ state errors by stepping in and out of the processes. I would try this with my original data, and later with parameters I know would succeed, just to get an idea of why this one works and the other one doesn't. I figured out that 404 errors happen while fetching from the wrong API URL so I messed up in my routing somewhere. If I get a 422 error unprocessable enty, that could be that I'm not passing in correct parameters from the frontend to the backend so I have to make sure what I'm passing in is what the backend is willing to accept. On the other hand, if I know what I'm sending the backend is 100% accurate, then a 422 error would mean that messed up on processing the data in the backend deals with the database, whether it be creating entries, joining models, relationships, querying the wrong entries, etc. ## Full-stack development solo takes a long time I have gotten alot better at organizing code. First time using React definitely made my code seem a little more organized. Never realized how much mental energy working 100% solo can be. I have worked on my own tasks individually on my last group project. ## Knowing when to stop It's been incredibly diffult to know when to stop. I feel most productive in the first 3 hours of work, but then my brain starts to go on a decline when it is lunch time, then get another burst of focus, and then completely dying off 2 or 3 hours later until the end of class. I felt like I was behind, so I decided to stay up all night with no sleep. And then I was performing poorly in the morning, the time where I was the most productive. It's not worht ## Conclusion It may not be perfect, but it is my creation and I'm willing to share my thoughts about the process and what I have learned.

_data.description: As a job seeker, it is incredibly easy to get into tutorial hell because there are so many jobs. I'll never be good enough for the job because I know these technologies.
_data.title: Tutorial Hell and Job Seeking

toc.text: Leaving my family made it easier
The straw that broke the camel's back
Living life as a plant based, compassionate human

children.value: As a job seeker, it is incredibly easy to get into tutorial hell because there are so many jobs. I'll never be good enough for the job because I know these technologies.

Ever since I was a child, two of my biggest concerns were solved by just changing my diet. I always questioned the morality of eating meat, and remembered seeing a black and white advertisement on TV showing kid of eating a hotdog. The message was pretty unclear, as I was only in 1st grade, but it definitely made me feel guilty for consuming animal products. There was a huge recycling and environmental craze in the early 90s, global warming was becoming a big deal and heard that more green house gas emissions come from factory farms than vehicles.

That being said, I was still not a vegan yet because as a child, we have very little choice on what we eat since our parents are the ones doing the shopping and are blinded by the cost of consuming animal products. In fact, nobody really knew what was happening behind the scenes in factory farms and believed the animals were given a happy life with no sense of suffering.
Leaving my family made it easier

When I joined the Navy, veganism wasn't on my mind at first because my first 4 years there were pretty rough, and it wasn't until I transitioned into a military linguist and studied at the Defense Language Institute where I discovered that they had a vegan options at the mess hall. I would eat black bean burger, salad, peanut butter sandwich and would feel great about being vegan. My original thoughts about vegan food was that it was all salads, but there are plant based options for anything! I wanted to discover more vegan options and went to shop at Trader Joe's, and boy did I discover a lot of nice vegan alternatives such as soy milk, Tofurkey, pad Thai, dairy/ egg free baked goods etc. One time on night shift, we all ordered some curry and I went to order some vegan curry, and boy was it one of the best things I tasted, this was one of the foods that made me want to try out more animal free dishes. I wasn't fully vegan, but mostly one because vegan options are rarely available and I didn't know how to cook.

After I left the Navy, I went back my home in Las Vegas and wanted to fully transition into becoming a vegan, but it was still very difficult. My mother hated my vegan diet since it limited her ability to cook what she wanted so I started small and just went lacto-ovo vegetarian.

One year has passed, I kind of forgot about my dreams of being a vegan because the food my mom made was so good, but it re-ignited again when I was preparing for a persuasive speech for my communications class. I was either going to talk about why we treat other animals favorably or veganism but then discovered another thought provoking question, why are we disgusted at eating insects, myriapods and arachnids? There were some research papers showing that it takes less water to a pound of insect, than even a pound of soy, which is already drastically lower than how much gallons it takes to produce 1 pound of beef. I care about the environment and it claims to save more water and easier to farm, but I would rather All forms of life, no matter the size, deserve to live a good life as well.
The straw that broke the camel's back

During this time, the Youtube algorithm started showing search recommendations of nothing but the horrors videos and it just grossed me out that I don't want to be a part of this anymore. Being shocked from what I witnessed, I decided to research facts about this diet as see that it also environmentally friendly and sustainable. Shows why veganism is unhealthy and would shorten my lifespan but I think more research needs to be done and know that the pros of going plant based out weighs the cons. The final straw that made me become cruelty free was when my English teach asked us why eating plants is better than eating animals, and one of the student claimed that it was healthier and prevents suffering.
Living life as a plant based, compassionate human

This was one of the best decisions I have made in my life and made me feel like a better person. I don't have the tendency to physically abuse my animals and friends as I did when I was in since Elementary School up until the middle of my adult life. Just like when I was thinking about why people don't eat land arthropods, I started questioning the meaning of life and suffering of others. It was an eye opener for me seeing through the lense of the animals being tortured and how we would say it is a crime to eat a dog or cat but it's okay to eat a cow or chicken?

Veganism isn't the perfect solution, but it is a step forward. The animals bred for consumption synethesize their own food like plants, they eat them, which means it's more energy efficient to just eat the plants they eat instead. Much of the world's environmental and economical problems can be solved by going vegan but unfortunately the animal based products are cheaper and profitable. We may find another food alternative to plants in the future the more we understand about how we stay health and get our energy. I will do my part and promote veganism by having my friends, family and colleagues try out meat alternatives.
